data.value: Find a root of a function in a bracketing interval using Brent's method.
Uses the classic Brent's method to find a zero of the function

on the sign changing interval [a , b]. Generally considered the best of the rootfinding routines here. It is a safe version of the secant method that uses inverse quadratic extrapolation. Brent's method combines root bracketing, interval bisection, and inverse quadratic interpolation. It is sometimes known as the van Wijngaarden-Dekker-Brent method. Brent (1973) claims convergence is guaranteed for functions computable within [a,b].

[Brent1973]_ provides the classic description of the algorithm. Another description can be found in a recent edition of Numerical Recipes, including [PressEtal1992]_. A third description is at http://mathworld.wolfram.com/BrentsMethod.html. It should be easy to understand the algorithm just by reading our code. Our code diverges a bit from standard presentations: we choose a different formula for the extrapolation step.
Python function returning a number. The function

The other end of the bracketing interval

Related functions fall into several classes:

signature: brentq(f, a, b, args=(), xtol=2e-12, rtol=8.881784197001252e-16, maxiter=100, full_output=False, disp=True)
references: Press, W. H.; Flannery, B. P.; Teukolsky, S. A.; and Vetterling, W. T.
*Numerical Recipes in FORTRAN: The Art of Scientific Computing*, 2nd ed.
Cambridge, England: Cambridge University Press, pp. 352-355, 1992.
